resource.description: The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases.

The Sequence Ontology Project (SO) is a joint effort by genome annotation centres, including: WormBase, the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project, FlyBase, the Mouse Genome Informatics group, and the Sanger Institute. They are a part of the Gene Ontology Project and their aim is to develop an ontology suitable for describing biological sequences.

ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided
Gene Ontology annotation uses evidence codes to indicate the type of evidence that supports the annotation.
The Gene Ontology (GO) project provides a controlled vocabulary to describe gene and gene product attributes in any organism.
The Non-Redundant Database (NRDB) of protein sequences in FASTA format from GenBank.

Concepts, definitions, terms, and resources for standardized description of a microarray experiment in support of MAGE v.1. The MGED ontology is divided into the MGED Core ontology which is intended to be stable and in synch with MAGE v.1; and the MGED Extended ontology which adds further associations and classes not found in MAGE v.1
InterPro is a database of protein families, domains and functional sites in which identifiable features found in known proteins can be applied to unknown protein sequences.
The Expressed Sequence Tags database (dbEST) contains sequence data and other information on single-pass cDNA sequences and is a division of GenBank.
Protein sequences from the Protein Data Bank (PDB) used for mapping protein sequences to crystal structures in PDB.
PDB Identifiers

Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis clone M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

resource.displayName: L. tarentolae contig sequences from Marc Ouellette
resource.description: Chromosome sequence for Leishmania tarentolae is provided by the CIHR Group on host pathogen interactions (Marc Ouellette, Jacques Corbeil, Barbara Papadopoulou, Michel J. Tremblay, Frédéric Raymond, Sébastien Boisvert from Université Laval, and Martin Olivier from McGill University). The CIHR group plans on publishing the completed and annotated sequences in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible. Permission should be obtained from Marc Ouellette before publishing analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a chromosome or genome scale.
Genes whose annotation has been updated recently at GeneDB.

resource.pluginArgs: --externalDatabaseSpec "%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%" --inputFile @downloadDir@/GOAssociations_Lbraziliensis/Lbraziliensis.gas --goExternalDatabaseSpec "Gene Ontology|1.748" --seqIdSql "SELECT g.source_id, taf.aa_sequence_id FROM dots.genefeature g, dots.transcript t, dots.translatedAAFeature taf WHERE g.na_feature_id = t.parent_id AND t.na_feature_id = taf.na_feature_id" --targetTable "DoTS::TranslatedAASequence" --lineOfEvidence "GeneDB" --inputIdColumn id --tolerateMissingSeqs --skipBadGOTerms @pipelineDir@/logs/badGOTerms.log
resource.description: L. braziliensis Gene Ontology associations from GeneDB.

T.brucei RPCI93 BAC End genome sequences from genbank.

Leishmania major strain SD 75.1 genome from WUSTL.

The Leishmania major (MHOM/SN/74/SD) was obtained from David Sacks (NIH). The properties of this line are described in here. A clonal derivative (75.1) was prepared by Deborah E. Dobson (Washington University School of Medicine) and used for sequencing.

Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA; this was prepared by Natalia Akopyants (Washington University School of Medicine).

Next-generation sequences on the 454 instruments were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was ~31X (Fragments 19X, 3Kb PE 9X, 8Kb PE 3X) using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as L_major_SD_1.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 1904 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 691kb (N50 contig length for the 4009 contigs was 27kb). The assembly spans 30.8Mb.

This work was supported by NIH grants AI29646 and AI 31078 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.

For questions regarding this L_major_SD_1.0 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen M. Beverley & Natalia Akopyants, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO. Sequence assembly – The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO. Citation upon use of this assembly in a manuscript:

It is requested that users of this Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.

resource.description:
This data represents protein expression evidence from the promastigote stage of L. braziliensis as described by Cuervo P et. al..
Data was provided by the Laboratorio de Pesquisa em Leishmaniose at the Instituto Oswaldo Cruz, FIOCRUZ, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

References:
Proteomic characterization of the released/secreted proteins of Leishmania (Viannia) braziliensis promastigotes. Cuervo et al. 2009 J Proteomics. 2009 Nov 2;73(1):79-92.
An exosome-based secretion pathway is responsible for protein export from Leishmania and communication with macrophages.Silverman et al.

Protein expression evidence from different stages (Amastigote, Epimastigote, Metacyclic, Trypomastigote) of T. cruzi provided by Rick Tarleton's group at the University of Georgia, Atehns, Georgia. The Center for Tropical and Emerging Global Diseases, University of Georgia, Athens, GA

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Peter Myler lab
resource.description: The chromosomal location of TATA-binding protein (TBP or TRF4), Small Nuclear Activating Protein complex (SNAP50), and H3 histones were assessed in Leishmania major using microarrays hybridized with DNA obtained through chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-chip). The TBP and SNAP50 binding patterns were almost identical and high intensity peaks were associated with tRNAs and snRNAs. Only 184 peaks of acetylated H3 histone were found in the entire genome, with substantially higher intensity in rapidly-dividing cells than stationary-phase. The majority of the acetylated H3 peaks were found at divergent strand-switch regions, but some occurred at chromosome ends and within polycistronic gene clusters. Almost all these peaks were associated with lower intensity peaks of TBP/SNAP50 binding a few kilobases upstream, evidence that they represent transcription initiation sites. Contact Peter Myler, peter.myler@sbri.org, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute.

resource.displayName: Splice Leader and Poly A Sites from RNASeq (George Cross)
resource.unpack: executeIdSQL.pl --idSQL "update apidb.NEXTGENSEQ_ALIGN set intron_size = regexp_replace(regexp_substr(query_id,'\(\d+\)','1'),'[\(|\)]','') where intron_size is null and sample in ('curated_polyA','curated_splice')"
executeIdSQL.pl --idSQL "update apidb.NEXTGENSEQ_ALIGN set strand = decode(strand,'+','-','-','+') where sample = 'curated_polyA'"

resource.displayName: T. brucei gambiense Experimental DGE Tags

manualGet.institution: Wellcome Trust Center for Molecular Parasitology

resource.description:
Digital Gene Expression tags (DGE) was applied to T. brucei gambiense. Publication is available from the PubMed http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20175885

Digital gene expression analysis of two life cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics. 2010 Feb 22;11:124.

resource.displayName: T. brucei gambiense Experimental DGE tags Frequencies

manualGet.institution: Wellcome Trust Center for Molecular Parasitology

resource.pluginArgs: --contact @TrypSageTags.Contact@ --arrayDesignName 'T.brucei gambiense SAGE Tags' --arrayDesignVersion '1' --studyName 'Transcriptome analysis of two life stages of Trypanosoma brucei gambiense' --studyDescription '' --freqFile @downloadDir@/TrypSageTagFreqs/freqs.tsv
resource.description:
Frequencies of tags that were observed in studies using RNA from T. brucei gambiense.

The digital gene expression (DGE) tags represent a 21 bp tag usually from the first NlaIII restriction site upstream of the poly A tail on mRNA transcript. A detailed description of the method and experiment is available in Veitch et al ( Veitch NJ, Johnson PCD, Trivedi U, Terry S, Wildridge D and MacLeod A. Digital gene expression analysis of two life-cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics, 2010, 11:124-137). DGE tags were created from three procyclic-form and three bloodstream-form Trypanosoma brucei gambiense STIB386 in vitro cultures. The 21bp tags have been aligned to the T.b.brucei 927 and T.b.gambiense Dal genome databases, allowing for up to a 2 bp mismatch. Tags that only align once to the genome are represented, so tags that are not unique are not present. The differential expression of bloodstream-form versus procyclic-form T.b.gambiense DGE tags is available to view for each tag.

Publication is available from the PubMed http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20175885

Digital gene expression analysis of two life cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics. 2010 Feb 22;11:124.

resource.description:
Mol Biochem Parasitol. 2010 Aug;172(2):141-4. Epub 2010 Mar 27. Histone H3 trimethylated at lysine 4 is enriched at probable transcription start sites in Trypanosoma brucei.
Wright JR, Siegel TN, Cross GA.
Laboratory of Molecular Parasitology, The Rockefeller University

The Crithidia fasciculata (strain/isolate Cf-C1) was obtained from Dr. Larry Simpson, University of California, Los Angeles. Genomic DNA was prepared by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to rminimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA, and was provided by Drs. Natalia Akopyants, Lon-Fye Lye and Stephen Beverley, Washington University School of Medicine.

A combination of next-generation sequencing and Sanger reads were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was 26X (Fragments 10X, 3Kb PE 14X, 8Kb PE 2X) and Sanger reads was .75X using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the CABOG software (Bioinformatics 24:2818-2824 2008). This first draft assembly was referred to as Crithidia_9.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants and had some remaining vector trimmed from contigs. The assembly is made up of a total of 1043 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 122kb (N50 contig length for the 2847 contigs was 28kb). The assembly spans 34.5Gb.

This work was supported by NIH grant AI29646 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.

For questions regarding this Crithidia fasciculata assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Crithidia fasciculata genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen Beverley, Natalia Akopyants, and Lon-Fye Lye, Department of Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequence assembly - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

It is requested that users of this Crithidia sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact the Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.
Scaffold sequences for C.fasciculata version 8.0 from WUSTL
Scaffold sequences for T.cruzi Esmeraldo version 6.0 from WUSTL
